summary: several zoonotic coronaviruses have expanded their host range into humans over the last 800 years. the virus originated in bats and spread into human populations by the use of camels as an intermediate host species (7, 8). the exact origins of the virus remain unclear. several mouse models have recently been developed to study MERS-CoV pathogenesis in vivo. these include a model employing adeno-associated virus delivery of hDPP4 (18), overexpression or knock-in of hDPP4 (20–23), and gene editing to generate mice carrying a chimeric mouse DPP4 (mDPP4) gene (24). the inability of MERS-CoV to infect these species is restricted, as is the ability to evaluate drugs and vaccine introducing mutations A288L and T330R allows mDPP4 to act as a functional receptor for MERS-CoV infection. the mutation helps stabilize a hydrophobic core in the MERS-CoV receptor binding domain (RBD) shown to be important for proper binding to DPP4 (29). mDPP4 acting as a functional receptor only when the glycan is absent (19). hDPP4, bDPP4, and cDPP4 orthologs are classified as permissive or nonpermissive (mouse, ferret, hamster, and guinea pig) orthologs categorized as nonpermissive have levels of infection that are not significantly different from those seen when no DPP4 is present. each DPP4 ortholog was measured in triplicate. only hDPP4, bDPP4, and cDPP4 had levels of infection significantly higher than hDPP4 (*, P 0.05 [Student's t test]). hDPP4 (yellow) complexed with the MERS-CoV RBD (red) (PDB code 4L72) hDPP4 (yellow) complexed with fDPP4 (green), haDPP4 (blue) and gpDPP4 (purple) orthologs suggest they can likely act as backbones to support MERS-CoV infection. a total of eight N-linked glycans are known to be present in the extracellular domain of hDPP4 (29) predictive software estimates that there are 7 to 11 putative glycosylation sites for each of the DPP4 orthologs analyzed in this study. PP4 receptor used in this study (from Pipistrellus pipistrellus pipistrellus) causing us to hypothesize that host restriction might be mediated by differences in the sequence or structure of gpDPP4 that are independent of this glycosylation site. all residues are numbered relative to the given DPP4 molecule. removing glycosylation from these three DPP4 orthologs did not result in an increase in infection. the levels of infection supported by all three glycosylation knockout molecules were not significantly different from those seen with the respective wild-type DPP4 molecules (P 0.05 [Student's t test]) the level of each DPP4 ortholog was measured in triplicate. only hDPP4 had levels of infection significantly higher than those seen in the absence of DPP4. the remaining DPP4 orthologs and glycosylation knockouts had infection levels that were not significantly different from those seen in the absence of DPP4. introducing select human amino acids into the mDPP4 sequence on blade V (A288L) acts to support MERS-CoV infection in combination with the blade IV glycosylation knockout (N328A) in the case of haDPP4, the L288 amino acid identity is conserved between the hamster and human sequences. this suggests that different determinants in haDPP4 and mDPP4 are responsible for blocking MERS-CoV infection. species-specific differences in blade V of haDPP4 are also responsible for haDPP4's inability to act as a functional receptor for MERS-CoV infection. many amino acid changes are required to make fDPP4 and haDPP4 permissive to MERS-CoV infection. combining three amino acid changes on blade V with the glycosylation knockout mutant on blade IV resulted in high levels of MERS-CoV infection. each DPP4 ortholog was measured in triplicate. hDPP4, fDPP4 (278) (330), and haDPP4 (289) gly had levels of infection that were significantly greater than those seen in the absence of DPP4. mDPP4 amino acids 247 to 504 allowed fDPP4 to support MERS-CoV infection. but no mutations were identified that could recapitulate the susceptible phenotype. we mutated residues on blade V and tried them in combination with the blade IV glycosylation knockout mutant (n331A) gpDPP4 and fDPP4 do not share their glycosylation sites with permissive molecules. removing glycosylation from bDPP4 caused no statistically significant change in its ability to support MERS-CoV infection. future studies are needed to determine whether changes on both blade IV and blade IV of gpDPP4 can confer permissivity. bDPP4, bDPP4, and bDPP4 gly had levels of infection that are significantly higher than those seen in the absence of DPP4. gpDPP4 and gpDPP4 gly had levels of infection that are significantly higher than those seen in the absence of DPP4. ror bars indicate mean values 1 standard deviation. the interactions between the virus spike and host cell receptor are crucial for mediating infection and for acting as a barrier for nonpermissive species. but viruses often overcome species barriers to expand host range. rat ACE2 is not permissive to SARS-CoV. introduction of a glycosylation site combined with a point mutation allows rat ACE2 to support SARS-CoV infection (43) this results highlight glycosylation as a key determinant of receptor species specificity for numerous coronaviruses. sylation site in bDPP4 did not affect its ability to support MERS-CoV infection. this suggests that the impact of the bDPP4 blade IV glycosylation site on receptor permissivity may be species specific. this suggests that further research should be performed to elucidate the additional changes that might allow gpDPP4 to act as a functional receptor for MERS-CoV. access to the crystal structures of these DPP4 orthologs would enable us to model changes in the MERS-CoV RBD that would allow the virus to successfully infect nonpermissive species. the generation of a transgenic small-animal model in these alternative species would require extensive genomic editing due to the number of mutations needed for each DPP4. permissivity data are indicated in the far right column, with green squares indicating permissive species and red squares indicating nonpermissive species, based on either in vitro or in vivo data (10–17). shaded colors indicate the group each species falls in. current data would postulate that all nonhuman primates are susceptible to MERS-CoV infection. but testing this hypothesis in vitro would help reveal whether any of these orthologs are nonpermissive. a mechanism other than glycosylation at our location of interest would be responsible for blocking MERS-CoV infection. further research to determine whether these other orthologs are permissive can help elucidate whether this region plays a broader role in the MERS-CoV infection susceptibility phenotype. more data on species permissivity will help determine whether DPP4 phylogenetic relationships can help inform receptor binding dynamics. rMERS-CoV-RFP tagged with tomato red fluorescent protein (rMERS-CoV-RFP) was engineered on the basis of the EMC2012 substrain. all recombinants were produced and studied under biosafety level 3 (BSL3) conditions. DPP4 orthologs were transfected into HEK 293T cells. these cells express little if any endogenous hDPP4. transfections followed a 2 BES protocol. Venus protein-tagged 945 plasmid was transfected in parallel with each experiment. at 20 h posttransfection, the medium was removed and each well was infected with 200 l of rMERS-CoV-RFP at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 5 for 45 min at 37°C. d by a factor of 537 to approximate the number of red cells in the entire well. cells were transfected with DPP4 constructs as described above. at 48 h posttransfection, medium was removed from each well. Proteins were separated using either a 6% (for DPP4) or an 8% (for actin) polyacrylamide gel. each sample, 15 g of the protein lysate was mixed with 6 loading dye. membranes were blocked in 1 phosphate-buffered saline–Tween 20 (PBST)–5% milk at room temperature for 1 h with shaking. membranes were incubated at room temperature for 10 min before imaging was performed. transfections were performed in 50-mm-diameter glass-bottom dishes seeded with 2 106 HEK 293T cells. cells were washed once with 1 DPBS and then fixed with 2 ml 2% paraformaldehyde. fluorescence indicated DAPI (4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole) staining for nuclei. at 20 h posttransfection, medium was removed and cells were washed with 1 DPBS. cells were counted and resuspended at a concentration of 5 106 cells/ml. the phylogenetic tree was generated using maximum likelihood and 100 bootstrap replicates with the PhyML package. the tree was visualized using EvolView (50) only bootstrap values of 50 are displayed. ml poly-l-lysine (Sigma)–1 Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline (DPBS) (Gibco) all cells were grown at 37°C with 5% CO2. all plasmids were grown at 37°C with 5% CO2. DNA3.1, 125 l of 1 M CaCl2 and distilled water (dH2O) were added to each sample in a dropwise manner. samples were incubated at room temperature for 45 min. each well was infected with 200 l of rMERS-CoV-RFP. transfected cells were infected as described above, except that an MOI of 0.1 was used. after 45-min incubation period, virus samples were removed and the cells were washed twice with 1 ml 1 DPBS. then 2 ml of 3% FBS medium was added to each well and the infection reaction mixtures were incubated at 37°C for 72 h. aliquot of each sample was diluted 1:5 and 10 l was added to a 96-well plate. a 200-l volume of coomassie Plus protein assay reagent (ThermoScientific) was added to each well, and the plate was incubated at room temperature in the dark for 10 min. Membranes were washed three times with 1 PBST (10 min per wash) before treatment with secondary antibody. blots used rabbit anti-goat horseradish peroxidase (HRP) (1:10,000)–1 PBST–5% milk and were incubated at room temperature for 1 h with shaking. cells were incubated with goat anti-DPP4 polyclonal antibody (R&D Systems) (1:50)–3% BSA–IFA wash. cells were washed three times with IFA wash and then incubated with secondary donkey anti-goat Alexa Fluor 488 (1:500) for 1 h with shaking. cells were washed twice with staining buffer and resuspended in 150 l staining buffer. at least 10,000 events per well were acquired on a Guava easyCyte HT flow cytometer (Millipore) for each read.
